newsitem.title: FRANCE: French Right has agreed election manifesto - report.
newsitem.headline: French Right has agreed election manifesto - report.

text.p: France's ruling centre-right coalition has agreed a broad campaign manifesto which pledges to cap public spending and help create jobs through lower payroll charges on low wages, the daily Le Monde said on Monday.

The manifesto, due to be unveiled on Tuesday, also contains a promise to meet the target for a single European currency, limit the number of government ministers to 15 or 20 and pursue decentralisation at both regional and departmental level, the newspaper said.
France will vote in a two-round snap parliamentary election on May 25 and June 1.

Le Monde said the centre-right coalition had borrowed a few ideas from the left-wing opposition in the five-page document agreed in broad terms on Saturday evening, including a cut in taxes on home-buyers and consolidating the pensions system.
The text notes the coalition's determination "to stabilise public spending so that it does not progress faster than inflation", but does not elaborate, the newspaper said.

Le Monde quoted the manifesto as pledging to forge ahead with privatisation, reform local taxes on companies, boost job creation schemes for small businesses and guarantee minimum benefits for the poorest.

On Europe, the text says the aim is to "succeed in achieving the euro (currency) on January 1, 1999" and also to institute "a true social Europe which would avoid unfair competition among European countries".

It pledges to ban politicians holding two offices -- as is the case with Prime Minister Alain Juppe, who is also mayor of Bordeaux -- to change regional voting procedures and to make the judicial system more accessible and faster.
Juppe said on Sunday that the coalition would carry out a 40-day flurry of legislation if re-elected.

Measures would include caps on public spending for five years, cuts in some taxes, efforts to help small businesses, a law to help the poorest and a review of whether to close a controversial nuclear plant.
